When SQL gets more complex it can be easier to maintain in the wiki if it is [[preformatted][.FitNesse.FullReferenceGuide.UserGuide.FitNesseWiki.MarkupLanguageReference.MarkupPreformatted]] instead of in a single line.

!2 Inline
!3 In Properties
We can use preformatted SQL in properties.

| Define Properties | Preformatted |
| key | value |
| .include | !-TestDatabase-! |
| cmd | {{{ 
select ID from TestData
 where Name ='%Name%' 
 
 and City ='%City%' }}} |

!| SQLCommand | Preformatted |
| Name | City | ID? |
| James | London | 6 |

!3 In SQLCommand
We can also use preformatted SQL in a SQLCommand table's constructor.

| SQLCommand | Preformatted | {{{ select ID from TestData
    where Name ='%Name%'

and City ='%City%' }}} |
| Name | City | ID? |
| James | London | 6 |

!2 Using a variable
But using preformatted SQL inside a table can make wiki pages hard to edit.
So we can also use [[variables][.FitNesse.FullReferenceGuide.UserGuide.FitNesseWiki.MarkupLanguageReference.MarkupVariables]] to contain the SQL statement.
Which will leave the wiki's source code much cleaner.

!define SQL ({{{
select ID
 from TestData
 where Name ='%Name%'
 and City ='%City%'
}}})
| Define Properties | Preformatted2 |
| key | value |
| .include | !-TestDatabase-! |
| cmd | ${SQL} |

!| SQLCommand | Preformatted2 |
| Name | City | ID? |
| James | London | 6 |

| SQLCommand | Preformatted2 | ${SQL} |
| Name | City | ID? |
| James | London | 6 |
